title: MASKING_POLICIES view | Snowflake Documentation
paragraphs: This Account Usage view provides the masking policies in your account.
Each row in this view corresponds to a different masking policy.
Internal/system-generated identifier for the masking policy.
Internal/system-generated identifier for the schema in which the policy resides.
Schema to which the masking policy belongs.
Internal/system-generated identifier for the database in which the policy resides.
Database to which the masking policy belongs.
Name of the role that owns the masking policy.
Type signature of the masking policy’s arguments.
Comments entered for the masking policy (if any).
Date and time when the masking policy was created.
Date and time the object was last altered by a DML, DDL, or background metadata operation. See Usage Notes.
Date and time when the masking policy was dropped.

The type of role that owns the object, for example ROLE. . If a Snowflake Native App owns the object, the value is APPLICATION. . Snowflake returns NULL if you delete the object because a deleted object does not have an owner role.

The value for the EXEMPT_OTHER_POLICIES property in the policy. If set to TRUE, the column returns { "EXEMPT_OTHER_POLICIES: "TRUE" }. If the property is set to FALSE or not set at all, the column returns NULL.
Latency for the view may be up to 120 minutes (2 hours).
The view only displays objects for which the current role for the session has been granted access privileges.
The LAST_ALTERED column is updated when the following operations are performed on an object:
DML operations (for tables only). This column is updated even when no rows are affected by the DML statement.
Background maintenance operations on metadata performed by Snowflake.
